video-config.troubleshootingIntro: If you're having any trouble getting your webcam set up, please feel free to email Kami at kamgar10@mit.edu and we'd be glad to help you out!

video-quality.title: Webcam setup for the study
video-quality.introText: Please check each of the following to ensure we're able to use your video:

instructionBlocks.text: Make sure the webcam you're using is roughly centered relative to this monitor. This makes it much easier for us to tell whether your child is pointing to the left or right!

image.alt: Example images of using centered external webcam on monitor or built-in webcam on laptop.

instructionBlocks.text: Turn off any other monitors connected to your computer, besides the one with the centered webcam. (If there's just one monitor, you're all set!)

image.alt: Example images showing laptop screen turned off if using external monitor and webcam, or external monitor turned off if using built-in webcam and laptop screen.

instructionBlocks.text: Check the lighting by making sure you can clearly see your own eyes on the webcam view to the right. You may need to either turn on a light or reduce light coming from behind you.

image.alt: Example images showing good lighting, room too dark, and backlit scene where eyes are not visible.

instructionBlocks.text: If it's practical, minimize exciting things that are visible behind or to the side of the screen--for instance, by facing a wall instead of the kitchen. (If this isn't practical for you, don't worry about it--just check the box!)

image.alt: Example images showing a child and puppy next to the computer, versus a computer just on its own.

video-quality.recordingInstructionText: You should be able to see your camera view above.

blocks.title: Overview of what will happen in this study

listblocks.text: You will be shown a series of 5 objects and asked to think of new ways to use them.
Explain your ideas to the computer by talking into the microphone. Your responses will be recorded.

blocks.text: Please try playing this sample audio to make sure you'll be able to hear the story.
blocks.title: Adjust your speakers

mediaBlock.warningText: Please try playing the sample audio.

webcamBlocks.title: Make sure we can see you

listblocks.text: Take a look at your webcam view above. Get comfy, and adjust your own position or the computer as needed so both you and your child are visible.

This isn't a Skype call - no one in the lab can see you - but the recorded video of your participation will be sent to the lab to help with data analysis. It's helpful for us to be able to see if your child was pointing or looking confused, for example.

debriefing.text:
Thank you so much for participating in this study! This study is based on a published paper (https://www.science.org/doi/full/10.1126/science.285.5433.1495). The main finding of the study was that structured algorithms produced outputs judged as more creative than those from humans given total freedom.

We'll be emailing you a $5 Amazon gift card - this should arrive in your inbox within the next week after we confirm that a child is with you in the video recording and check that your child is in the age range for this study. If you don't hear from us by then, feel free to reach out! Please donâ€™t hesitate to contact me at kamgar10@mit.edu if you have any additional questions or feedback!
debriefing.title: Thank you for your participation!

exit-survey.additionalVideoPrivacyText: Data will be available for viewing only to the students, faculty, and teaching assistants in the class for the duration of the class and will be deleted by December 20th, 2023.
